item.description:
@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The first military ‘mines’ were not explosives but rather

… timber-braced tunnels dug underneath stone fortifications, such as castle walls.

(think old-time manual labor coal or silver mine tunnels, with pick-axes and little wooden carts)

1/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Once complete, the wood inside was set on fire, and a few hours/days later the tunnels collapse and undermine the stone walls.

~ ~ ~ ~

Modern naval torpedoes work the same way; they are often set to explode beneath the keel of a large ship, not hit the ship directly.

2/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki The resulting shock wave rocks the ship and causes some damage…

… but the real fun starts when the pressure dissipates but before the water can rush back in.

(Spoiler: gas is compressible, water effectively isn’t, and ships are very heavy)

3/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki Basically, there’s nothing supporting the center of the ship anymore (aka a nautical sinkhole), and hopefully the now-damaged keel cracks from the uneven support.

~ ~ ~ ~

I imagine bridge piers don’t like their foundations to suddenly ‘blink out of existence’ either.

4/4

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki (I wouldn’t be surprised if the mere threat of a nearly-completed mined wall had occasionally led to the occupants of besieged fortifications to surrender at the last moment … before the mine was lit afire; averting catastrophic damage)

#NotAHistorian

item.description:
@daniel_balos @zahed @gardenrichard True, but it’s only about 50 years old, right?

“Soviet bridge; strong like ox.”

Once the now-exposed steel oxidizes, though, and after a few freeze-thaw cycles… long-term it’s probably ‘totaled’.

@stefan_meyer98 @zahed @gardenrichard There are a lot of ways to use it for low volume traffic (far under design loads) in good weather.

Even if damaged much further, it could still serve as a useful foundation / formwork for a temporary bridge (once Ukraine again has control of the area and isn’t under fire).

@stefan_meyer98 @zahed @gardenrichard Risk profiles (even for civilians) are much different in wartime, after all!

@mem_error @maryjo_miles @zahed @ChrisO_wiki I wonder if it could be ‘mined’ (in the medieval sense of the term) using some kind of second-hand tunnel boring machine (TBM), or even a oil-rig-style directional boring system…

item.description:
@NobodyK83030025 @ValeenC @zahed Folks can try something similar at home!

By pressing one’s hands inward (post-tensioning), three to five tin cans of food or soda can be suspended horizontally in the air.

(With enough inward force, another person can even apply a mild bit of ‘simulated live load’ to the top.)

@zahed @SigmaBob Plus, all the custom formwork for any prefab segments is likely long gone.

With changes in government, they might not even have complete and accurate construction drawings anymore.

(Small cracks in a major post-tensioned bridge in Seattle has closed it down for years.)

@zahed @ulrichwi @HeinzDieterDetl Probably also depends to what extent the Soviets over-engineered their bridges, right?

(i.e. If they were extra-conservative with safety margins and careful in construction, it may hold up better than some of the ramshackle post-war construction in North America.)

item.description:
@sarahbeanz @robmorris123 @Pandora_HasABox @fiona_mugure Often that is because component-level parts and schematics are not furnished by the manufacturer.

Even now, (nearly?) every major appliance sold in the US (& for 70+ years), has a schematic hidden inside!

(The same was true for many TVs and radios for much of the past century.)

@sarahbeanz @robmorris123 @Pandora_HasABox @fiona_mugure If there was demand for repair (and parts availability), repair costs would drop with scale.

Many people may also feel more empowered to tinker and learn - even easier now with YouTube - in those down periods, such as after putting the kids to bed for the night.

#RightToRepair

@Curvycutie69 @DouglasNicol8 @natefernald Many old TVs (mostly CRTs and the first decade or so of some flat-panel plasma/LCD models) actually had room for the speakers to be on front, actually facing the room.

Sadly, it appears that ship has sailed.

item.description:
@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Indeed.

Change should happen, and multiple strategies (in parallel) are probably in order.

We can investigate pricing/transparency and at the same time enlist everyone possible (in this case, young HCWs), to ease the transition to wherever we end up next.

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Agreed!

For something more straightforward, though, small decisions that have no measurable effect on outcomes, can have significant costs.

(e.g. brand vs. generic drug prescribing decisions in context of the loss of free t-shirts, lunches, and coffee mugs for fear of bias)

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Consider a stable patient that could justifiably be discharged from a hospital in the evening vs. the next morning.

The knowledge that 12 extra, unnecessary, hours as an inpatient might cost them hundreds or thousands of extra dollars probably should factor into that decision.

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas Okay, I think y’all actually agree on most of this, then.

If you can know that MRIs are expensive, and therefore only order them judiciously… and also are cognizant of that, so you aren’t overly biased to avoid them…

… then we should teach all three of those, eh?

1/2

@DrKittensaurus @margaritaloxas It seemed @margaritaloxas was noting students aren’t taught how expensive many services/procedures can be, esp. when all of the ancillary charges are added up.

(There are examples in the replies about vastly unnecessary ambulance trips recommended in a perfunctory way.)

2/2
